content.webTitle: Nottingham Forest and Barnet upset as ESPN pulls plug on women's final

fields.headline: Nottingham Forest and Barnet upset as ESPN pulls plug on women's final
fields.bodyText: ESPN's decision to scrap its planned television coverage of the women's Premier League Cup final on Thursday has angered the contestants, Nottingham Forest and Barnet, both of whom have lost potential sponsorship deals that were linked to TV exposure. "We had two sponsorships lined up on the understanding that the game would be on TV," said the Forest secretary, Fay Glover, whose club were recently close to extinction due to lack of finances. "Getting to the final has helped us raise enough money to keep going until the end of the season but the extra cash we could have raised would have been a massive help." ESPN's decision was due to a perceived lack of interest in the final, to be held at Wycombe Wanderers' Adams Park, according to the Football Association's head of national game, Kelly Simmons. "At the point a decision had to be made on whether to go ahead with the broadcast, we were concerned about low ticket sales," she said. "It's normal that we sometimes have changes in our scheduling, as in this case," added the ESPN spokesman Paul Melvin. The fears of a meagre crowd seem to have been unfounded. "We anticipate in excess of 2,000," said the Wycombe secretary, Keith Allen. That figure is much higher than the attendances expected in the forthcoming Women's Super League, six matches from which are due to be televised by ESPN. "We played a Super League club [Birmingham] in the FA Cup last week and there were only a hundred spectators," said the Barnet secretary, John Taylor. "And they told us they were expecting crowds only in the low hundreds for WSL games." Barnet will head into the final as the Premier League's bottom club after a 2-1 defeat at Millwall Lionesses. Forest, second in the table and without a weekend League fixture, fell five points behind the leaders, Sunderland, who won 1-0 against third-placed Leeds.
